data.author: Sarah Derouin
data.title: Zipping Up Data to Zap It Back from an Icy Moon
data.description: NASA wants to send instruments to distant moons like Europa and Enceladus to search for life. But getting vital data back to Earth over limited bandwidth will take some impressive compression software.
data.source: Eos: Earth And Space Science News

data.title: Invasive species leave behind their friends, hindering colonization
data.description: For invasive species leaving their home, they leave not only their predators but also the species that helped them thrive.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Glaciers in the Alps are melting faster than ever—and 2022 was their worst summer yet
data.description: Finally, after what was arguably the worst summer on record for glaciers, snow has begun to fall in the European Alps. It is much needed. Over the 19 years that I have visited and studied the glaciers in Switzerland, I have not seen a summer like 2022. The scale of change is staggering.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Energy agency: CO2 emissions rise in 2022, but more slowly
data.description: The International Energy Agency said Wednesday that it expects carbon emissions from the burning of fossil fuels to rise again this year, but by much less than in 2021 due to the growth in renewable power and electric cars.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Rapid full-color Fourier ptychographic microscopy provides new solution for digital pathology
data.description: Fourier ptychographic microscopy (FPM) is a promising computational imaging technique to realize high-throughput pathological imaging in medical diagnosis. However, existing FPM colorization approaches suffer from a trade-off between color precision and efficiency.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Ocean heating will increase rainfall in east Asia, study suggests
data.description: Upper ocean heating in the equatorial Pacific—a key oceanographic region in Earth's climate system—is likely to make the East Asian monsoon season wetter, according to a study co-authored by a Rutgers researcher.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.author: Eric A. Taub
data.title: E.V.s Start With a Bigger Carbon Footprint. But That Doesn’t Last.
data.description: The manufacturing and disposal of electric vehicles result in more greenhouse gases than nonelectric models, but that difference will eventually disappear altogether.
data.source: The New York Times

data.title: Converting carbon dioxide to solid minerals underground for more stable storage
data.description: A new scientific review article in Nature Reviews Chemistry discusses how carbon dioxide (CO2) converts from a gas to a solid in ultrathin films of water on underground rock surfaces. These solid minerals, known as carbonates, are both stable and common.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: UK Faces Science and Tech Drain
data.description: The UK risks an exodus of some of its most promising science and technology businesses, according to a new research report. Almost one in six (16%) have firm plans to relocate overseas over the next three years and 88% have considered it. Building a Future for Science and Technology, by Ridge and Partners, the multi-discipline property and construction consultancy, suggests a key driver of this discontent is the government’s lack of understanding of the sectors’ needs...
data.source: Lab Bulletin

data.title: After 2018 Woolsey wildfire, LA's mountain lions are taking more risks
data.description: Los Angeles is known for its movie stars and beaches. It's also known for being one of only two megacities in the world that supports a population of big cats. Despite being surrounded by a vast network of busy freeways and over ten million people, mountain lions have somehow managed to eke out a living in the wooded LA-area hills. Now, researchers reporting in Current Biology on October 20 have found that wildfires, and specifically the 2018 Woolsey fire, are putting the LA mountain lions' future in more doubt.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Insights into pathogen-host interaction offer clue to protecting crops from blast disease
data.description: A mechanism used by a fungal pathogen to promote spread of the devastating cereal crop disease, blast, has been revealed in fine detail.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Endangered birds can be protected from predators with chemical camouflage
data.description: Researchers used artificial nests to test two methods for reducing the nest predation of vulnerable and endangered ground-nesting birds. The study showed that red foxes can be more easily deceived into not eating bird eggs than raccoon dogs. The methods could be used alongside hunting and offer an alternative, non-lethal solution for creating protection for vulnerable prey.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Sickly shades of gray: Disease outbreaks influence the color of wolves across North America
data.description: New research from the University of Oxford, Yellowstone National Park, and Penn State, published today in the journal Science, may have finally solved why wolves change color across the North American continent.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: World's largest no-fishing zone benefits fish and fishermen
data.description: A study published in the journal Science shows for the first time that carefully placed no-fishing zones can help to restore tunas and other large, iconic fish species. It is well known that no-fishing zones can benefit sedentary marine life, like corals or lobster; but until now, it was assumed that no marine protected area (MPA) could be big enough to protect species that travel long distances, such as tunas. This recovery is good news not only for the environment, but also for the global tuna fishing industry, which generates $40 billion in revenues each year and supports millions of jobs...
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.author: Andrey Feldman
data.title: A portable spectrometer built using a “lab on a chip”
data.description: A mini, portable tool to measure light could improve everything from smartphone cameras to environmental monitoring.The post A portable spectrometer built using a “lab on a chip” appeared first on Advanced Science News.
data.source: Advanced Science News

data.title: Mammalian oocytes store mRNAs in a mitochondria-associated membraneless compartment | Science
data.description: A membraneless compartment clusters mitochondria and stores maternal mRNAs in oocytes of various mammalian species.
data.source: Science | Aaas

data.title: Engaging the unengaged: Exploring citizen participation in nature-based solutions in China
data.description: Pressing unsolved environmental issues such as super-storms, floods, droughts, and heatwaves have become a critical challenge in many Chinese cities, such as Beijing and Guangzhou.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Social media damages appearance satisfaction
data.description: New research has discovered that social media engagement is associated with lower appearance satisfaction, and engaging with posts by friends and family is more damaging than engaging with content posted by celebrities.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Are you a mosquito magnet? It may be because of your smell, new study suggests
data.description: Do you ever feel as if mosquitoes are always biting you and seem to target you? It may be because of your smell, a new study says.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Characterizing the cis-regulatory evolution of the gene WntA in nymphalid butterflies
data.description: A combined team of researchers from Cornell University and The George Washington University, has characterized the cis-regulatory evolution of the gene WntA in nymphalid butterflies. In their study, published in the journal Science, the group used a variety of techniques to better understand how gene regulatory processes in a type of butterfly can allow for both deep homology and speedy adaption to environmental changes.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Eels are some of nature's weirdest creatures—5 reasons why they're such cool little freaks
data.description: It's the question that baffled scientists for hundreds years—where on Earth do eels come from?
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Like an invisible pair of tweezers, sound waves can levitate tiny objects in the air
data.description: While DIY acoustic levitation kits can be found online, the technique has important applications for research and industry including manipulating sensitive material such as biological cells.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: New tool helps researchers study remote glaciers
data.description: As warming atmospheric temperatures lead to glacier thinning and retreat around the world, understanding how glaciers are responding to climate change, algal growth, and impurities like dust and black carbon is vital. Understanding the response helps scientists, policymakers, and communities mitigate harm and protect watersheds and communities that rely on these glaciers. However, many glaciers are located in remote locations that can be difficult to access and study.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: Project debunks the idea that conservatives think the world is more dangerous than liberals
data.description: For anyone paying attention in the lead-up to the United States midterm elections, it should come as no surprise that people who consider themselves politically conservative see the world differently than those who consider themselves politically liberal.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology

data.title: What a buzzkill: Early-ending winters disrupt bumblebee slumber
data.description: Gardeners across North America and different parts of the world have been growing worried over an eerie quiet settling over their gardens—a silence caused by the missing buzzing of bees.
data.source: Phys.org - News And Articles On Science And Technology
